metadata.value: A page of French text in black ink divided into two sections. Each section has further notation to the right. At the bottom of the page is a "P" shaped design in black ink, though it is not clear what it is meant to be.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Letters are in various hands, presumably those of the copying clerks of the Privy Seal and the Signet, a few with the subscription of John Prophete, possibly the original owner of this book. Prophete was a king's clerk during the reign of Richard II, and died as Dean of York in 1416. An inscription on the last leaf refers to another owner, Thomas Nicolls (probably a notary); it reads Sum liber Thome Nicolls. Laing purchased this MS from the sale of Arthur Taylor, F.S.A., in 1871, when it was bound with another work (MS 178).
metadata.label: Provenance Notes

metadata.value: A page of Latin text in black ink, divided into two parts. The second part is larger than the first, and has a further notation to the right hand margin.
metadata.label: Description
